Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 07:17AM cynthiaintx wrote: Guess I'm squeaking in here by the skin of my teeth, surgery is this Friday the 30th!  Having a lumpectomy, had surgical consult yesterday, all pre-op is done, now it's just the waiting.  I'm getting tired and frustrated at all the run around by the insurance company, but the folks at the hospital have been great.  Except the gal at the surgeon's office.  She was kind of a ...well, you know. Of course, it has to be a super-busy work week!   Settling in for the wait....
Posts.Title: August 2013 Surgeries laura11103 babs6287

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 06:54PM cynthiaintx wrote: I think it depends on the medical team. y kind of needle inserted into the body is going to cause some discomfort. Some of us handle pain with a different tolerance than others. My needle core biopsy was wonderfully painless (a little pulling sensation, but that's it), and my surgical team was incredible! Same radiologist who did the biopsy did the wires - and again, no pain. You do stand for awhile, because your boob has to be in the mammogram machine. That's done with local anesthesia. My surgery was done with a general - good thing, the doc said it took a little longer than expected. But even the surgery had minimal discomfort (removed a tumor the size of a grape). Now, my radiologist was a special lady - she went into her career field because her mom had breast cancer. I'm so thankful to have been her patient - the breast center is now on my Christmas cookie list! The key word is COMMUNICATION! Be sure to say you want a local to have the wires inserted.The lidocane feels like getting a flu shot, no big deal.
Posts.Title: Why do they tell you one thing then it changes at pre-op appt?? gtgirl gtgirl

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 06:42PM cynthiaintx wrote: You won't know anything until you have the pathology report back from the biopsy. I had mine in 24 hours - when told I had DCIS, I said "thank you Lord!" If you have to have it, that's the kind to have... Anyway, take it one day at a time. You are not 100% diagnosed. When I had my mamo and ultrasound, the radiologist said it didn't look good... and indeed, it was a slow-growing tumor. Surgery was shortly after, they got everything, and now I'm going through radiation. So far, so good! Please don't worry, it doesn't add a minute to your life. Do your homework, be educated, but worry is not going to help. Go out with friends, have a good cup of coffee, pick some apples, go to the museum. Don't worry.
Posts.Title: 45 yr old found a 3cmx1.5cm AnnieeC Janet456

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 11:08PM - edited Aug 24, 2013 11:08PM by cynthiaintx Does every lumpectomy get this wire?  My spot is very shallow and can be easily felt.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Told different stories about wire localization IrishDancingMom dogsandjogs

Posts.Content: cynthiaintx wrote: Whew.  So, had my first mammogram and ultrasound today - to make a long story short I was without health insurance, and was very low income/underemployed for quite some time.  Now that I have a better job AND good insurance, well, it's catch-up time.  The lump has been there for some time, over a year, so I'm glad I'm getting it taken care of NOW. The radiologist gave me the report that she wants to do a core needle biopsy asap - so that happens on Tuesday the 20th.  I'm getting the feeling from what everyone is saying that there will be a surgery, to just what extent, however, will depend on the biopsy. I live by myself, but have a good group of friends, a few who have already been through this, and an incredible church family.  I'm looking on this whole thing as a big inconvenience in life, but it has to get done.  At this point - well, throughout the whole process to come - it has to be viewed as one day at a time, imho.... Is there a faith-based forum, or thread? One day at a time... I Sam 17:45 Back in hosp 9/10 due to pulmonary embolism Dx 8/21/2013, DCIS, 1cm, Stage 0, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/29/2013 Lumpectomy: Left Radiation Therapy 10/2/2013 Breast Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just came back from the Breast Center... cynthiaintx cynthiaintx

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2013 05:02PM cynthiaintx wrote: Pffft... I got this.  Like I told a friend, I'm preparing for the worst, praying for the best.  Cleaning house like crazy in case I'm out with a surgery, and that's keeping me plenty busy!  Might find some recipes for freezer meals (I live by myself) and I already have a friend who will take my dogs if I have to be in the hospital.  I know that I don't know anything yet, and am not worrying.  Concerned, of course, but worry?  Not gonna solve anything.  As Matthew 6:27 says, worry won't add a day to my life.  I've had several surgeries in my life, and while they are in no way fun, I made it through just fine.  I have a very strong faith, and it's only being made stronger. In fact, I'm viewing this right now as a huge pain in the butt that I really don't have time for, so let's get it over and done with.  I have too many other things to do.  Then again, I'm kind of a crusty ol' Texas cowgirl who doesn't tolerate nonsense very well!
Posts.Title: Just came back from the Breast Center... cynthiaintx cynthiaintx

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 11:05AM cynthiaintx wrote: So send her back, and don't get too worried.  I know, easier said than done!  Until you have more information, it's so easy to get worried sick.  "Abnormal" can mean a whole bunch of things, but until there's more info - and a biopsy is a way of obtaining that info - worrying won't make things better. Hoping that everything turns out ok!
